title: Prohibits the state from entering into certain contracts with companies requiring employees to stipulate to binding arbitration for all disputes
summary: Prohibits the state from entering into certain contracts with companies requiring employees to stipulate to binding arbitration for all disputes unless it excludes disputes involving sexual assault.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1729

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the executive law, in relation to prohibiting the state from
entering into contracts with companies requiring employees to stipulate
to binding arbitration for all disputes

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
To prohibit the state from entering into contracts, or renewing
contracts, with certain companies requiring employees to agree to
binding arbitration contracts for all disputes, including but not
limited to, sexual assaults.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
Section 1 amends the executive law by adding a new section 170-c which
would prohibit the state from entering into contracts, or renewing
contracts, with certain companies requiring employees to agree to
binding arbitration contracts for all disputes, including but not
limited to, sexual assaults.

JUSTIFICATION:
Many companies require workers to sign binding arbitration agreements
as part of their employment contracts, which require employees to
forego their right to seek legal remedies for all disputes with the
employer, including those arising from sexual assault and other
assaults.

Workers who are sexually assaulted while working for defense
contractors overseas typically have few options. They cannot bring
charges in the country where the crime was committed, and the binding
arbitration clause bars them from using courts in the united States.

In one of the most infamous cases arising from this practice of
overseas contractors for defense corporations, Jamie Leigh Jones, a
20-yr-old employee of defense contractor KBR, who was stationed in
Iraq, stated she was gang raped by her co-workers and imprisoned in a
shipping container when she tried to report the crime. Her father and
her congressman fought to secure her safe return to the United
States, but once home, Ms. Jones learned a fine-print clause in her
KBR contract banned her from taking her case to court, instead
forcing her into an "arbitration" process that would be run by KBR
itself. Ms. Jones was forced to go to court to sue for the right to
get justice, and after several years of litigation, she received a
favorable ruling, allowing her to seek justice. She has been pursuing
the matter in court since 2005.

In 2008, a number of female employees of overseas defense contractors
testified before the U.S. Senate Armed Services Committee. According
to Sen. Bill Nelson of Florida, who cited Defense Department
statistics, more than two dozen female contractor employees working

in Iraq and Afghanistan have reported being raped or sexually
assaulted. One of the women testifying, Dawn Leamon, a mother of two
active duty military personnel, stated she was drugged and brutally
gang-raped by soldiers and coworkers. She said KBR's employee
assistance program discouraged her from filing a formal report.

It is time the State of New York took measures to end this abhorrent
behavior and help the employees assaulted overseas to gain justice.
By barring contractors who require their employees to sign such
binding arbitration agreements from contracting with the State of New
York, this state will step forward and help protect the employees who
are unable to find justice under current law and practice.

PRIOR LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
None.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
Indeterminate.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately.
